title: How to Deflate a Basketball with or without a Needle

steps.title: Insert a lubricated inflation needle.
steps.content: Insert a lubricated inflation needle. Wet the inflation needle with water (some people lick it, but that isn’t exactly hygienic). Push the needle inside your basketball’s round valve opening.You'll hear a hiss of air. [1] X Research source An inflation needle is a small metal rod with a pointed end. You can find one at any store that sells sporting goods, or you can buy one online.

steps.title: Wait for the air to release before removing the needle.
steps.content: Wait for the air to release before removing the needle. If you just want to remove a little air from an overinflated ball, this only takes 2 or 3 seconds. If you’re completely deflating your ball, apply extra pressure by squeezing it as the air releases. [2] X Research source Then pull the needle out gently, being careful to not yank out the valve.

steps.title: Do a bounce test to see if your ball is game-ready.
steps.content: Do a bounce test to see if your ball is game-ready. Hold your ball like a referee, extending your arm upward so your ball is even with the top of your head. Drop your ball: if it bounces up to elbow height, it’s properly inflated. If your ball bounces lower, add more air . If it bounces higher than your elbow, release a bit more air. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Insert a ball air pressure gauge.
steps.content: Insert a ball air pressure gauge. Lubricate the tip of a ball air pressure gauge with water or glycerin before placing it in the valve. [4] X Research source This gadget measures the PSI (pounds per square inch, or kPa) of air in a ball. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Press the release button on the gauge to let out the air.
steps.content: Press the release button on the gauge to let out the air. [6] X Research source The air pressure gauge has a button located on the side. Push and hold the button down to release air from your basketball.

steps.title: Remove the gauge once the pressure is correct.
steps.content: Remove the gauge once the pressure is correct. Examine your ball for pressure specs. Most basketballs have inflation instructions printed on them. If the instructions are worn off, rely on the standard of 7.5 - 8.5 PSI (51.71 - 58.60 kPa). [7] X Research source Monitor the gauge and gently remove it from the valve when it displays the correct pressure. It’s game time! [8] X Research source

steps.title: Stick a straightened, lubricated paper clip in the valve.
steps.content: Stick a straightened, lubricated paper clip in the valve. Make one end of the paper clip as straight as possible. Lubricate the straightened end with water, then sit in a chair with your basketball held firmly between your knees. Gently slide the straight end of the paperclip into the valve. [9] X Research source This method isn’t as reliable as using an inflation needle or pressure gauge. It’s possible to damage the valve with the sharp metal end of the paperclip, so be gentle!

steps.title: Remove the paperclip after a few seconds.
steps.content: Remove the paperclip after a few seconds. If you're trying to slightly deflate an overinflated basketball, it will only take a few seconds to release the air. Or, leave the paper clip in longer if you’re trying to flatten your ball. Once you've let out as much air as you want, carefully slide the paperclip out of the valve. [10] X Research source You can squeeze your ball a bit to speed up the process, but don’t exert too much pressure or you might damage your ball.

steps.title: Try a bounce test to tell if your ball is at the right pressure for playing.
steps.content: Try a bounce test to tell if your ball is at the right pressure for playing. While holding your ball, extend your arm upward so your ball is even with the top of your head. Drop your ball: if it bounces up to elbow height, it’s properly inflated. If it bounces lower, add more air by inflating your basketball . If it bounces higher than your elbow, release more air. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Stick a bobby pin inside the valve.
steps.content: Stick a bobby pin inside the valve. Listen for a hiss of air as you push the closed end of a bobby pin inside your basketball’s valve. [12] X Research source If you can’t hear any air, spread the prongs of the bobby pin apart slightly. This widens the valve opening. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the bobby pin after a few seconds.
steps.content: Remove the bobby pin after a few seconds. Once your basketball has deflated for a few seconds, pinch the prongs of the bobby pin shut. Gently slide the bobby pin out of the valve. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Perform a bounce test to find out if your ball is ready for the court.
steps.content: Perform a bounce test to find out if your ball is ready for the court. Hold your ball even with the top of your head and drop it. If it bounces higher than your elbow, release air; if it bounces lower, add air to your basketball . If it bounces up to your elbow, you're good to go! [15] X Research source

steps.title: Take apart a ballpoint pen.
steps.content: Take apart a ballpoint pen. Remove the ink chamber from a ballpoint pen and take off the nib. Wash out the ink chamber, or snip off a portion of the chamber that doesn’t contain ink. [16] X Research source A ballpoint pen is better than a gel pen because gel pens have thicker chambers.

steps.title: Stick the empty ink chamber into the valve.
steps.content: Stick the empty ink chamber into the valve. After lubricating the ink chamber with water, apply gentle pressure as you slide it into your basketball’s valve. You’ll hear a hiss as the air escapes your ball.

steps.title: Wait for the air to release.
steps.content: Wait for the air to release. It will only take a couple of seconds if you just need to reduce the pressure a bit. To deflate your basketball fully, it will take a minute or two. You can squeeze it to release the air more quickly. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Conduct a bounce test to know if your ball is ready to shoot hoops with.
steps.content: Conduct a bounce test to know if your ball is ready to shoot hoops with. Before hitting the court, hold the ball so it’s even with the top of your head and drop it. If it bounces up to elbow height, game on! If it bounces lower, add more air to your basketball . If it bounces higher than your elbow, deflate it a bit more. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Place your basketball in the fridge.
steps.content: Place your basketball in the fridge. Keep the basketball inside the refrigerator until it’s cold. (Expect questions from your roommates or family about why there’s a basketball in the fridge!) The pressure will drop about 1 PSI (6.9 kPa) after an hour in the refrigerator. [19] X Research source Extreme temperatures change the amount of pressure inside a ball. Cold temperatures reduce the pressure because the air molecules have less thermal energy. Science! [20] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the ball and do a bounce test to see if it's ready to play with.
steps.content: Remove the ball and do a bounce test to see if it's ready to play with. Hold the ball so it’s even with the top of your head and drop it. If it bounces up to elbow height, it’s perfect for playing. If it bounces lower than your elbow, inflate your basketball a bit more. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Chill the ball again if needed.
steps.content: Chill the ball again if needed. If your basketball bounces higher than your elbow, it’s still overinflated. [22] X Research source Squeeze your ball to release a bit more air, then put it back in your fridge and repeat the process.
